critique: This executive order promotes the use of American-made goods and services in federal procurement. It aims to strengthen domestic industries and support American workers. It establishes a Made in America Office within the OMB to oversee waiver processes and promote transparency. It also directs agencies to review and update their practices to align with the policy. It revokes previous executive orders related to Buy American policies and emphasizes the importance of enforcing the Buy American Act of 1933. The order does not directly address immigration, civil liberties, or social inclusion. It focuses primarily on economic and trade policies related to domestic production. It could be seen as protectionist, which aligns with certain conservative economic views, but also with some progressive views on supporting domestic labor. The emphasis on federal oversight and centralized review processes suggests a slight increase in federal control. The focus on domestic production could be seen as somewhat restrictive in terms of international trade.
